title: 111_s3936
content: The Act is titled the "States as Energy Leaders for the Future Act" or "SELF Act". It defines terms like "eligible entity" and "Secretary". The Act establishes a Clean Energy Grant Program. The "States as Energy Leaders for the Future Act" establishes a Clean Energy Grant Program in the Department of Energy to provide grants for clean energy and carbon reduction measures on a competitive basis. This includes renewable electricity standards, climate action plans, use of alternative fuel vehicles, energy efficiency measures, participation in greenhouse gas reduction programs, and innovative financing mechanisms for clean energy technologies. The Clean Energy Grant Program aims to provide grants for clean energy initiatives such as renewable electricity standards, energy efficiency upgrades, innovative financing mechanisms, grid technology improvements, and carbon efficiency standards. Eligible entities must meet requirements set by the Secretary and submit an application for consideration. The Secretary will determine grant recipients and amounts based on specified criteria. The Secretary will determine grant recipients and amounts based on information provided in applications and criteria developed by regulations. Grant funds must be used for eligible purposes specified by the Secretary. Regulations will establish criteria for grants, eligible measures, application criteria, and a point system for reviewing and ranking applications. The Secretary will use a point system to review and rank grant applications, considering regional energy disparities and clean energy potential. An explanation will be published on how grants ensure objective evaluation based on established criteria. Authorization of $5 billion for fiscal year 2011 to carry out the Act, with funds remaining available until expended. Cost offset for clean energy grant program and deficit reduction by denying deduction for major integrated oil companies for income from domestic production of oil, gas, or primary products. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include oil related qualified production activities for major integrated oil companies. The amendment also denies deduction for income from domestic production of oil, gas, or primary products for these companies. These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010.
